item.title: Ticket #745 (categories.php in admin produces an irrelevant nb of posts for the ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
to solve: on delete category, then put posts in default category

AND remove duplicates in table post2cat

e.g.

DELETE FROM $wpdb->post2cat AS pc1, $wpdb->post2cat AS pc2 WHERE pc1.post_id = pc2.post_id

AND pc1.category_id = pc2.category_id AND pc1.rel_id > pc2.rel_id

item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy

weird... the bug doesn't occur when i'm not logged.

the bug works as such: it fetches one too much post in the db, for some reason.

i see:

​http://www.semiologic.com/cogent-confabulation/

followed by:

​http://www.semiologic.com/2005/03/12/cogent-confabulation/

obviously, the bug can also be solved by editing the template, so you might as well downgrade the priority to minor.

item.title: Ticket #1233 (Date/Time options should ask for DST "zone") updated
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1233 (Date/Time options should ask for DST "zone") created
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description:
It should be possible to select from possible DST zones so WordPress can account for Daylight Saving Time in those regions. Only storing an offset from UTC doesn't account for Daylight Saving Time.

Here are all the possible DST regions:

​http://webexhibits.org/daylightsaving/g.html. DST could be accounted for by doing a simple test to see if UTC+offset is within these dates (i.e. the time should be calculated as UTC+offset+DSToffset, where DSToffset is 1 only if within the limits from the above website)

item.title: Ticket #1232 (Editing comments use "now" as the timestamp) updated
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1232 (Editing comments use "now" as the timestamp) created
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description: When editing a comment, one has the option to adjust the timestamp. The timestamp, however, defaults to "right now," instead of the existing timestamp. This makes it difficult to adjust the timestamp relative to its old value (when one, for example, needs to adjust dozens of comments to account for daylight saving time, since WordPress fails to do it automatically).

item.title: Ticket #1231 (Can't use feed names as a slug with some permalink structures) updated
item.dc:creator: raena
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1231 (Can't use feed names as a slug with some permalink structures) created
item.dc:creator: raena
item.description:
If you have date-based permalinks like yyyy/mm/dd/slug, and your slug happens to be the name of a feed, someone clicking its permalink will see a feed instead of the post.

You can see this in action on this post of Matthew Thomas', here: ​http://mpt.net.nz/?p=36

The proper permalink for this can be seen in the URL on the headline, which is: ​http://mpt.net.nz/archive/2004/09/30/atom

But clicking it gets an Atom feed for September 30th.

His site still uses an alpha from 1.3, but I've replicated this on a 1.5 install.
